DataElement.preferredDefinition: The type of biospecimen collected by biopsy procedure.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: The removal of tissue specimens or fluid from the living body for microscopic examination, performed to establish a diagnosis._Executed and carried through to completion.:Any material sample taken from a biological entity for testing, diagnostic, propagation, treatment or research purposes, including a sample obtained from a living organism or taken from the biological object after halting of all its life functions. Biospecimen can contain one or more components including but not limited to cellular molecules, cells, tissues, organs, body fluids, embryos, and body excretory products._The act of gathering things together; having been brought together in one place._Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: The removal of tissue specimens or fluid from the living body for microscopic examination, performed to establish a diagnosis._Executed and carried through to completion.

Executed and carried through to completion.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Tissue sample that contains an abnormal cellular infiltrate forming a solid mass. The abnormal cellular component can be benign or malignant. Tumor samples are obtained for microscopic examination and/or molecular analysis._The use of cup forceps to obtain a tissue sample free of cautery effects.

Concepts.definition: Tissue sample that contains an abnormal cellular infiltrate forming a solid mass. The abnormal cellular component can be benign or malignant. Tumor samples are obtained for microscopic examination and/or molecular analysis.
The use of cup forceps to obtain a tissue sample free of cautery effects.

PermissibleValues.value: Cold cup biopsy of normal-appearing tissue neighboring tumor

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Normal Appearance Tissue Near Tumor Tissue Sample Biopsy
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Having no anomalies or unexpected findings on visual inspection._An anatomical structure consisting of similarly specialized cells and intercellular matrix, aggregated according to genetically determined spatial relationships, performing a specific function._Not far distant in time or space or degree or circumstances._Tissue sample that contains an abnormal cellular infiltrate forming a solid mass. The abnormal cellular component can be benign or malignant. Tumor samples are obtained for microscopic examination and/or molecular analysis._The use of cup forceps to obtain a tissue sample free of cautery effects.

Concepts.definition: Having no anomalies or unexpected findings on visual inspection.
An anatomical structure consisting of similarly specialized cells and intercellular matrix, aggregated according to genetically determined spatial relationships, performing a specific function.
Not far distant in time or space or degree or circumstances.

Tissue sample that contains an abnormal cellular infiltrate forming a solid mass. The abnormal cellular component can be benign or malignant. Tumor samples are obtained for microscopic examination and/or molecular analysis.
The use of cup forceps to obtain a tissue sample free of cautery effects.

Concepts.definition: The removal of tissue specimens or fluid from the living body for microscopic examination, performed to establish a diagnosis.

Any material sample taken from a biological entity for testing, diagnostic, propagation, treatment or research purposes, including a sample obtained from a living organism or taken from the biological object after halting of all its life functions. Biospecimen can contain one or more components including but not limited to cellular molecules, cells, tissues, organs, body fluids, embryos, and body excretory products.
The act of gathering things together; having been brought together in one place.
Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.
